FacilityName: TYSON FOODS, INC. (N. LITTLE ROCK, AR.)

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EPA RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN



EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



TYSON FOODS    NORTH LITTLE ROCK, AR.



1.  Accidental release prevention and emergency response polices. To insure safe operation and release prevention at Tyson Foods NORTH LITTLE ROCK, AR., this facility has implemented The Occupational Safety and Health Administrations Chemical Process Safety Management Program 29 CFR 1910.119.  All operators of systems containing the threshold amount of hazardous chemicals will undergo Chemical Process Safety Management training and operator training specific to the system. 

To insure proper response to emergency situations, Tyson Foods NORTH LITTLE ROCK,AR., has implemented Emergency Action Plans as required by The Occupational Safety and Health Administrations 29 CFR 1910.38(a) and Emergency Response Plans  29 CFR 1910.120. All safety personnel and operators of the process will be trained in these emergency procedures.



2.  The stationary source and regulated substances handled. The Tyson Foods, inc., North Little Rock processing facility is in the southeastern part of the city at 3800 Progress St. in the central part of Arkansas. Approximately 185 people are employed to process raw material used in production each week. these raw materials (chicken, batter, breader) are used to produce chicken wings. our products are flash fried, then frozen for storage and 100% of our production is shipped to other locations for storage and distribution.  Approximately 20,000 lbs. of anhydrous ammonia is used in the refrigeration systems for the cooling, processing, freezing and storage of product.



3.  The general accidental release prevention program.  This facility complies with the Occupational Safety and Health Administrations Chemical Process Safety Management 29 CFR 1910.119 and the Environmental Protection Agencies Risk Management Program 40 CFR Part 68.  For ammonia systems Tyson Foods, Inc. has adopted the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration guidelines for system

operation and maintenance.  Tyson Foods Inc. uses the IIAR Basic Ammonia Refrigeration Training Series for all operators.  

  



4.  Five-year accident history.

     None



5.   The emergency response program.  A written Emergency Response Plan has been developed and is on record at the Facility.  This plan includes Pre-Emergency Planning with Outside Agencies, Personnel Roles and Lines of Incident Command Authority, Facility Hazard Analysis and Emergency Prevention, Safe Distances and Places of Refuge, Site Security and Control, Evacuation Routes and Procedures, Decontamination Procedures, provisions for Emergency Medical Treatment, Emergency Notification Procedures, Chemical Response Procedures, Post Incident Critique, and Personal Protective Clothing and Emergency Equipment.



The Emergency response plan has been written to understand and safely respond to the incidents in the Incident Command structure.  The Emergency Response Plan includes but is not limited to the following:

I?   Pre-Emergency planning and coordination with any outside agency.

II?  Hazmat Team personal roles and Line of Authority.

III? Hazmat Communication.

IV? Emergency Recognition and Prevention.

V?  Standard Operating Guidelines.



?    Health Hazards

?    Emergency and First Aid procedures 

?    Physical Hazard

?    Materials to avoid

?    Additional Information

?    Spill of Leak response for Vapor Ammonia

?    Spill of Leak Response for Liquid Ammonia

?    Decontamination

?    Small Leak Response for inside the facility



All Team members are taught to report any observed chemical leaks/spills and odors to their supervisor or lead person immediately.  Supervisors and Leads are taught to report the above to the Safety or Process Manager immediately for further investigation.  MSDS information books are accessible to all team members for review.
